title: Cardinal becomes first English saint of the modern age
text:
Prince Charles, Prince of Wales meets Pope Francis during the canonisation of Cardinal Newman in St Peter’s Square (Picture: Getty Images Europe)

Thousands gathered in St Peter’s Square today to mark the historic canonisation of Cardinal John Henry Newman.

Newman was an influential 19th century figure who shocked the Victorian world by renouncing his academic career at Oxford University to convert from an Anglican priest to Catholicism in 1845.

He became an immensely influential unifying figure in both the Anglican and Catholic churches with the sainthood hailed as an important moment in UK-Vatican relations.

Prince Charles led Britain’s representatives at the open-air ceremony in the Vatican City, where Pope Francis declared the cardinal a saint in front of thousands of pilgrims.

It makes Cardinal Newman the first English saint of the modern age.

The last Brit sainted was John Ogilvie, the 17th century Scottish martyr of the reformation, who was canonised by Pope Paul VI in 1976.

Prince Charles said the way the theologian had stood up for his ‘convictions’ still resonated today in light of the persecution groups and individuals faced because of their beliefs.

He added: ‘In the age when he lived, Newman stood for the life of the spirit against the forces that would debase human dignity and human destiny.

‘In the age in which he attains sainthood, his example is needed more than ever – for the manner in which, at his best, he could advocate without accusation, could disagree without disrespect and, perhaps most of all, could see differences as places of encounter rather than exclusion.’

Melissa Villalobos, the subject of the second miracle attributed to Cardinal Newman and which confirmed his status as a saint, said: ‘God in his mercy and Cardinal Newman in his sweet humility granted my request, thanks to God.’
description: Pope Francis cannonised Cardinal John Newman at St Peter's Square, the Vatican, to make him first English saint of the modern age
